pros: The pros of working for Beebe Healthcare are very few. I would say that they are a company that is in the midst of change. The Operations Manager is very intelligent and makes working under his guidance fulfilling. I would say that another plus would be that working in Healthcare IT is an essential job. The last pro would be that you will be able to do something different everyday.
cons: The biggest con of working for Beebe Healthcare would be the company culture. The culture is very cutthroat. Employees often will take a minute complaint to management with the intent to get a coworker terminated. Office politics are rampant and quickly lead to new employees growing sour with Beebe. The lack of team cohesiveness is also a major problem.  There is a very serious lack of communication, respect and trust between the Network, Telecom and Desktop teams.

review_title: Human resource services inconsistent and slow
pros: Very positive management attitude from top down. True desire to improve and to address change, improvement and problem solving, but lost in process. Terrific benefits and concern for employee welfare. Very community oriented, many free programs for people to maintain or improve health.
cons: Inconsistent application of management, enforcement of policies, rules; Leadership members lack  authority or confidence to make changes or discipline. Few true leaders, tied up in meeting after meeting. Long time employees have lock on jobs regardless of the productivity. It's who you know or who you're related to.

pros: Patient care is foremost. Beebe values are high on all employee's lists.
cons:
Growing too fast without proper infrastructure of staffing. Too many employees are kept as casual and used as full-time without any benefits.
Management seems oblivious to under-staffing and yet makes more and more demands of those who are trying to keep the growing population served.

pros: co workers are nice as can be, good pay, good benefits
cons: You will constantly work overtime, work thru lunch (you cant eat at your station so you can just starve) , you are expected to take call after working a 12 hours shift then get called several times in the middle of the night and be back to work the next morning.  There is no support.  You will be worked to death and stressed beyond what is imaginable. Many unsafe working conditions. There is no life work balance.

job_title: Doctor of Physical Therapy- Homehealth in Lewes, DE
pros: Great benefits including 401 k, health/dental/vision- we used to have $0 deductible but now it's $250 a year....as long as you stay with Beebe docs it's pretty much covered. Staff members are awesome, a true team, direct bosses care for employees and are good business professionals.
cons: Pay is NOT competitive for SLP, OT, PTA, PT, PT. all Beebe takes into account is years of experience- not if you have an advanced degree (doctorate) or if you are in a certain field like Homehealth. Every year I threaten to quit since all of us get job offers about once a week it would be easy....and they give me a decent raise. Not sure if I will stay in upcoming years...love my job but if the money really matters it's not the job for you. HR doesn't get how in demand therapists are and the keep paying travelers BIG money because the can't recruit PT's in the area secondary to salary. Beebe board members wake up....baby boomers are getting older and you need therapists bad...along with every other hospital, assisted living/nursing home and rehab center in this retirement (beach) community.

pros: Good benefits package & hourly rate is average to above average with national figures. Longevity of many team members, making for a family like atmosphere.
cons: This longevity of many team members is also it's con, with a common phase of "it's the Beebe way." They are not open to new ideas or a more efficient process from new staff who come with many years of experience. This has lead to new employees leaving & taking their experience with them to other area hospitals.

pros: It is a great place to work, it cares about there patients and it is always trying to be number 1 when it comes to JACO,
cons: It does not look out for their employees.

pros: Coworkers like family, great to get to know everyone so well being such a small facility. Great location to live.
cons: Being so far away from other similarly sized facilities means if you want to work somewhere else, you would likely have to move. (Somewhat remote location)

review_title: experienced nurses need not apply, PACU
pros: really nice coworkers, truly amazed how nice they are in the face of what they have to deal with on a daily basis. theyre overworked, understaffed, leaned on to work way more than other hospitals and because of that their personal time is being taken advantage of. All are mostly working their full time day shifts with a steady stream of overnights and weekends, when all are hired for a simple day shift with on-call.
cons:
unbelievably slow HR process to get hired, took months to get everything in order and I have a very basic, simple application with great references and experience. My unit comprised of many soon-to-be retirees, meaning many of the large issues at hand turned a blind eye because of complacency and impending retirement. 
         I was misinformed about what my schedule would be on the interview versus what the reality is, which I spoke out on. Patient care standards are very low at times and many docs pass the buck around, by the time anyone gets around to helping the acute urgent issue at hand the patients fall thru those cracks causing them to be worse off then they needed to be, had someone acted faster. Safety of patients, and standards of care came into question weekly, I approached management and HR, unfortunately the hospital has high census, meaning they have to deal with that first ensuring the flow of patients in and out, causing many of these issues to fall to the wayside and only to re-emerge as urgent situations, which happens.
large teaching hospitals have a lot checks and balances, standards in place, rankings to consider and are on the offensive, setting high standards. This hospital seems to be running on the defensive, if ever they can catch up.  Manager seems to be a middleman, without having much executive power. It's not magnet, and they have a higher census coming in then their own capacity even allows for causing patients to back up in the ED and any unit that has rooms especially the post sugical unit. They will attempt to alter acuity of a patient to move them to a room that's available, even though that patient may require closer monitoring then that unit provides.
Compensation is no more better than nearby. i would try not to be a patient here.

pros: Everyone works together like a family
cons: Like with families, they can be dysfunctional. Communication can be lacking and ineffective. Departments are very siloed. Management makes knee jerk decisions without the proper stakeholders present.

pros: The frontline staff are what make it worth going to work every day. They’re down to earth, dedicated and loyal. Many of them have been there forever.
cons: Senior management cares more about budget and avoiding lawsuits than patient care. HR is incompetent/hateful. There is basically no opportunity for advancement.

review_title: Front line staff give great care!
pros: Staff provides great care in a very busy facility.
cons: Often work short staffed, middle management seem to only worry about keeping staffing numbers low. Also, they do have favorites.
